ORDER granting 2778 Motion In Compliance. Given that Secretary Gonzalez has given immediate and personal attention to address this unprecedented and paramount health measure for the participants, the Commonwealth is granted the requested extension, as to which USDOJ and Monitor have no qualms. More so, the Court notes that Secretary Gonzalez is most familiar with the case and the JCAP, given that in his previous tenure in the position, the JCAP was approved by the Court. The JCC, Secretary Gonzalez with counsel, and USDOJ will coordinate a teleconference over the weekend so that there be a meeting of the minds, to the greatest extent possible. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/10/20. (Gelpi, Gustavo) (Entered: 04/10/2020)

ORDER: Noted 2948 Motion Submitting Preliminary Reopening Plans. The JCC shall within 21 working days (local holidays also excluded) provide his comments to the DSPDI's reopening plan to DSPDI and USDOJ. The parties and JCC will then meet via teleconference to discuss the same. This is a matter in which consensus is crucial. If the parties reach consensus or are unable to do so, the JCC shall so inform and the Court will provide further directives. The Court notes that its intention was that DSPDI provide its plan and then the JCC and USDOJ provide their comments. Any previous order which can arguably be interpreted otherwise should be disregarded as to this matter only. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/16/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 07/16/2020)

ORDER: The Court notes the JCC's Informative motion at Docket No. 3008 and DSPDI's response at Docket No. 3011 . Both were filed in light of the Court's Amended Order at Docket No. 3006 . More so, the Court is aware that JCC and DSPDI have been in communication and that DSPDI has been providing information prior to the Order at Docket No. 3006 . This is not an issue and the Court has not been misinformed. What the JCC's informative motion exactly pertains to is all remaining information following the entry of the order at Docket No. 3006 . Thus, the Court is clearly not holding DSPDI accountable at this time for information due tomorrow. The Court is not in the habit of entering orders on weekends, unless of an urgent nature, or as here to avoid all misunderstanding. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 8/9/2020. ORDER: Noted 3185 Motion In Compliance with Order to Show Cause as to 3177 Order. Notwithstanding, the Court expects that this matter be resolved by the October 22, 2020 status conference (given that this matter is on agenda). While Therap may indeed be a third party provider to DSPDI, this was as a result of the JCC finding Therap and convincing DSPDI, USDOJ and ultimately the Court, that such services were essential and necessary. If the matter is not resolved affirmatively by October 22, the Court will not hesitate in taking the necessary action. ORDER: Noted 3208 Informative motion regarding Docket No. 3206. The matter of the polypharmacy meeting was addressed by the Court minutes ago in its order at Docket No. 3207. The separate MRC meeting shall also take place as directed by the JCC. This is an initial meeting intended for the benefit of DSPDI and the participants. It is no adversarial meeting as the JCC is not a party, but rather a collaborative one, as the JCC and DSPDI have done in the past for many years. More so, the Court notes that DSPDI after almost twenty years of being subjected to a federal consent decree calling for court monitoring would now want to reexamine how matters are coordinated, run and by whom, to wit, under its own terms and conditions. If DSPDI wants to litigate the matter it should do so with USDOJ who is the other party to this consent decree case, and not the JCC, who is simply acting on the Court's behalf as he had done so for two decades without issue. The Court notes DSPDI's continued objections at Docket No. 3206. The same, however, are not reason for not complying with the Court's directives in enforcing the consent decree before it. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/14/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/14/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3209 Informative Motion regarding United States' Comments on Commonwealth's Revised Homes Plan. This matter is on agenda for the October 22, 2020 status conference (Docket No. 3196). Accordingly, the parties will now have to focus on remedial measures. Again, this is another matter that DSPDI has seemingly neglected to adequately address. From the Court's perspective, thus, all positive momentum in this consent decree has long since ceased and the Commonwealth is backtracking to 1999. This is the second occasion in weeks that USDOJ has asked the Court to take remedial action (something that has never before occurred). Moreover, USDOJ -more than once in its motion- posits that DSPDI has ignored court orders, as well as its recommendations. This case finds itself at a crossroads. If the Commonwealth cannot effectively act, drastic remedial action is looming in the horizon. Justice Ginsburg's legacy in Olmstead is a civil rights beacon of hope to all participants, whom the United States Department of Justice and this Court have been called to protect. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/14/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/14/2020)

ORDER: For purposes of the Court-ordered meetings subject of Docket Entry Orders Nos. 3249, 3250, and 3255, the JCC has full and complete authority to facilitate, coordinate, and preside over the same in the manner he prescribes at the commencement of each meeting. Moreover, the JCC, as an officer of the Court, may also (as in the past) submit directives at the meeting itself, or in advance and in writing, as to the mode, manner and order of each meeting. The parties, their experts and staff, as well as counsel, are expected to fully cooperate with the JCC. All are reminded as well that following each meeting or series of meetings, the JCC is tasked with issuing a corresponding report to the Court. Moreover, such meetings are collaborative exercises and not litigious ones. The Court moreover in these meetings is giving DSPDI the opportunity to resolve the many issues that have arisen, rather than have to take the immediate remedial action it has advanced may ultimately be the only necessary alternative. ORDER. The Commonwealth at Docket No. 3489 has submitted its position as to the JCCs March 29, 2021 draft Report. See Docket No. 3489 . Specifically, the Commonwealth states that it determined not to submit comments nor recommendations. This is hereby NOTED. Rather, the new government administration once again expresses its current approach of proactive cooperation towards comprehensive compliance. Moreover, the Commonwealth represents that it will continue to wholly cooperate with all monitoring efforts from the JCC Office during this reporting period and will aggressively work towards compliance. This is also NOTED. The Court once again applauds the Commonwealths focus in avoiding litigation challenging the consent decree and monitoring, and more importantly, prioritizing the needs of the Participants. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/22/2021.(sc) (Entered: 04/22/2021)

ORDER: Noted 2944 Motion regarding Delayed Payments to Service Providers. The Court's independent investigator, attorney & CPA Diana Alcaraz, will inform the Court by Wednesday, July 22, 2020 of all outstanding payments due to providers as of this date. DSPDI will immediately provide all urgent data and information requested by the special investigator. This is a recurring problem that consumes unnecessary time and effort of all. For almost a decade and a half, the Court has had to revisit the matter time and time again, each occasion with the guarantee that this will not occur again. Yet, like the Hydra it arises again. Once these payments are issued, the Court will take further immediate action and provide strict directives so that provider invoices for payments and reimbursements are duly paid in a swifter, briefer and more effective manner. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/15/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 07/15/2020)

ORDER: Granting 2950 Motion for Leave to File Spanish language documents. This motion is granted as follows: First, see Order at Docket No. 2811 which notes that USDOJ is at a disadvantage when it cannot review the Spanish language documents. Second, the Court grants DSPDI until July 29, 2020 to translate the documents. However, if USDOJ requests an earlier uncertified and/or unofficial translation it must immediately be provided, even if verbally. Third, DSPDI documents such as the reopening plan are frequent in this case. They must diligently be translated and submitted in English. Otherwise prompt resolution of any matter is stalled. Thus, DSPDI needs to have a translator on call at all times as this is a federal court proceeding where the applicable and only language is English. This norm, going on forward, will apply not only to pleadings filed, but also to all matters where USDOJ counsel is present. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/16/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 07/16/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3033 Response To Order To Show Cause. At this time the Court notes DSPDI's compliance with outstanding payments. However, this is a systemic and recurring issue which in the past (under different administrations), every assurance to resolve the same has not worked. As USDOJ and the JCC have well noted and the Court indeed concurs its is definitely time to promptly adopt a more effective, speedier method. There is simply no excuse that in August of 2020 this whole process cannot be digitalized to work and yield prompt results. Accordingly, the Special Investigator during the remainder of this week and next week will meet with DSPDI personnel and agree to a revised method of processing and paying provider payments. If there are any bureaucratic hurdles outside DSPDI and the Health Department they shall also note this. The Special Investigator will then submit a report to the Court on the matter. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 8/12/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 08/12/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3155 Informative motion. DSPSI shall by tomorrow Tuesday, September 29 by 5:00 p.m. inform and explain to the Court why its is applying different standards (abnormality versus symptom based assessment) as means of Covid-19 prevention at the Agape Mitchell and Erickmar homes for participants. ORDER: Noted 3233 Informative motion. DSPDI shall provide to the JCC the requested monitoring information and documents on or before Tomorrow, Thursday October 22, 2020 at 5 p.m. DSPDI's repeated failure to timely comply with the JCC's requests continues to be an issue. See Order at Docket No. 3230 . Moreover, the JCC should not have to oft appear before the Court akin to a party seeking compliance with a subpoena. This is an enormous waste - albeit necessary - go the Court's time. The Court intends to take prospective remedial action as to this recurring problem which DSPDI is incapable of resolving, and hence, results in unwarranted delays in the compliance, monitoring, and enforcement of the consent decree at bar. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/21/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/21/2020)

ORDER: DSPDI's Response to the JCC's Informative Motion (Docket No. 3247 ) was filed contrary to the procedure set forth in the Court's Order at Docket No. 3056 . The same requires the parties (USDOJ and DSPDI) when filing any such motion to certify that prior to doing so it conferred with the opposing party (in this instance, USDOJ). In addition, at footnote 1 DSPDI adduces that the JCC under the consent decree is impeded from filing informative motions, moreover, that his communications to the Court are limited to very few and specific circumstances. This again, constitutes an attempt to limit the JCC's deputized authority, and is contrary to the long-standing practice adopted by the Court in this case. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/26/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/26/2020)

ORDER: Denying 3270 Motion for Reconsideration. Denied. The Commonwealth mischaracterizes the facts, ignores its many failures as well as takes inappropriate efforts to attack the Court, the JCC, and the United States. It generally seems to misunderstand almost everything about the legal framework of this case. The Commonwealth's arguments deflect attention away from its many missteps, while focusing a negative spotlight on the Court, the JCC, and the USDOJ all purportedly acting in concert as if conspiring to harm the DSPDI program. Granting the request for more time on said grounds would constitute carte blanche so DSPDI can continue to act with impunity in violation of the consent decree. The Court, thus, denies the request for reconsideration on the grounds adduced in the Commonwealths motion. Notwithstanding, the Court is willing to entertain a joint motion of the parties requesting for a reasonable extension. For this, DSPDI and USDOJ must, however, confer and concur. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/3/2020. (MET) (Entered: 11/03/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3298 Informative motion regarding In-Person Assembly. The Court shares the JCC experts' concerns. This event, no matter the precautions taken, places at risk providers, and, in turn, participants. Does DSPDI foreclose a superspreader effect? Is it really necessary to hold this event live now? Cannot the same be held virtually? The Court, for example, remains closed until at least February 11, 2020, upon consulting with its own epidemiologist and other experts. Even the judges meet virtually for most matters requiring multiple persons to gather. All of this, in an abundance of the utmost caution. DSPDI shall inform the Court this afternoon by 6:00 PM its position as to whether it will postpone the event, or otherwise hold the same virtually. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/20/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 11/20/2020)

ORDER. The Court laments Dr. McGee's unexpected passing. In light of this event, the Court hereby APPOINTS Dr. Sylvia Fernandez as Joint Compliance Coordinator ("JCC"). Dr. Fernandez will immediately assume all of Dr. McGee's duties and shall have the same authority conferred upon her. A more detailed order shall issue forthwith. The Court notes that Dr. Fernandez has been the Assistant JCC for two years, and closely worked with Dr. McGee during that period. She is thus by far, the most qualified candidate to continue assisting the United States and PR Health Department, and monitoring compliance with all court approved agreements. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/27/12.(cr) (Entered: 11/27/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:Further Status Conference held on 11/18/2013. Present inchambers were Attorney Richard J. Farano on behalf of the United States. AttorneyArlene R. Perez-Borrero on behalf of the Secretary of Health, Beatriz Annexy-Guevara, Charlene Reagan, as well as Court monitor, Sylvia M. Fernandez, Ph.D., and Dr. Greduvel Duran, Undersecretary of Health were also present. Parties discussed various matters related to the report of the Health Department. The Court will meet with the parties and coordinate visits to the homes. After hearing the parties the Court imposed the following deadline: The Health Department shall deposit funds to pay all pending invoices to JCC and Staff on or before 12/02/2013. The Court notes that these invoices are oustanding since August and September 2013. Further Status Conference set for 1/27/2014 at 2:00 PM in Old San Juan Courtroom before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi. And an additional Status Conference is set for 1/30/2014 at 2:00 PM in Old San Juan Courtroom before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi. (al) (Entered: 11/18/2013)

ORDER: The parties' joint motion 2212 is hereby noted. The Court is flabbergasted by the fact that since approval of the JCAP in 2011, the MRC has not performed its function, and has not even come close to acting at an acceptable level. The Commonwealth is hereby ordered, on or before 3/25/18, to provide in a restricted motion all of the information requested by USDOJ at page 7 of its motion. The Court advances that it will set a hearing as to this matter at a date to be announced. If warranted, the Court will explore all possible remedies for the JCAP MRC non-compliance. This may include a receivership for MRC, if convinced the situation will persist. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on March 7, 2018. (DVL) (Entered: 03/07/2018)

ORDER: Noted 2222 Motion In Compliance. The Court at this time will not make a contempt finding. However, the sanction of $50 per Health Department Official for belatedly submitting statements to the JCC stands. A final tally shall be made and the Commonwealth will then be required to pay the total sanction. Although nominal, orders are orders and these must be complied with for the reasons stated by the Court. Just last night -- the Sunday before the public hearing -- the JCC informed that he was continuing to receive information from DSPDI. This cannot occur again. Judge Lopez, if warranted, may modify the order of Health Department Officials who appear, and also extend the hearing past Tuesday. These late submissions have highly burdened the Court, for example requiring that the undersigned last night request assistance from a second magistrate judge for duty matters that Judge Lopez would attend to during breaks during public hearings, and also having the JCC, Judge Lopez, and the undersigned to communicate at bedtime. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on March 12, 2018. (DVL) (Entered: 03/12/2018)

ORDER denying 2517 Motion to Continue. The Court is perplexed. The parties and JCC agree as to all matters at issue. Subsequently, the Commonwealth files a battery of motions responding to those previously filed by the JCC ie, Docket Nos. 2518, 2519, 2520, 2522 & 2523. Given this, Judge Lopez shall hold the scheduled status conference and address the matters referred to him at Docket Nos. 2511 & 2513. In addition he shall address those in the Courts order at Docket No. 2512. Judge Lopez shall make a detailed minute of all stipulations and agreements, as well as issue any warranted orders, as well as deadlines regarding the plethora of matters before the Court. These are all of the utmost priority given their impact on the lives and well-being of the participants. One of these matters involving social security was previously discussed at last years final status conference and was subject of an internal audit. The Court then forewarned that a receivership limited to the matter could ensue if not resolved. Judge Lopez shall issue deadlines, which if not strictly complied with result in further action by the Court. Given the Commonwealths financial woes, the Court would not like to have to consider thus the prospect of contempt and sanctions. Finally, the JCC and staff need to urgently have office space. The work of the JCC has increased over the last half decade and it is no longer feasible for the Court nor parties to expect him to provide his private office for meetings, document storage and all other matters. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7-5-19. (Gelpi, Gustavo) (Entered: 07/05/2019)

ORDER RE DOCKET NOS. 2744 & 2745 : The Court's emergency order at Docket No. 2744 provides for measures to be followed absent any other protocol implemented by DSPDI. Given this, counsel for DSPDI and USDOJ shall confer and discuss the measures and requests proposed by DSPDI. The parties shall jointly report any such agreement(s) immediately. The JCC shall participate in any such discussions. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 3/20/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 03/20/2020)

The Commonwealth shall on or before 3/24/20 agree as to a protocol with USDOJ. The same must be based on consensus reached by the parties with the input of the JCC. The Court clarifies that restricted home visits do not apply to clinical and other professionals, as long as the necessary COVID-19 safeguards are in place. Unless the Court issues an order directing otherwise the emergency order, as well as the JCAP and all other court orders in this case remain in effect unless trumped by federal law or order. ORDER: Noted 2760 Informative Motion regarding Proposed Action Plan and Protocol; Noted 2760 Motion Submitting Proposed Action Plan and Protocol. The Court notes the comprehensive COVID-19 protocol submitted by the JCC, prepared following the submission of the Commonwealth's draft protocol. This protocol contains the several crucial items addressed by the DSPDI COVID-19 Task Force, and now has the benefit of adding the recommendations made by the JCC's team of expert consultants from the U.S. Mainland, and also takes into account observations of the participants, relatives and providers, as well as any related court order. It is thus perhaps the most comprehensive document that can be prepared in such a short time frame with an imperative call to action from all. The Commonwealth/DSPDI will inform by tomorrow March 30, 2020 before 5:00 p.m. whether the protocol is acceptable to is as an initial working tool during this pandemic. Time is of the very essence as the pandemic number of infected persons and deaths is on the rise. More so, the protocol as it is now presented may be readily amended as conditions change. SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 3/30/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 03/30/2020)

ORDER: The Court has again carefully reviewed the comprehensive COVID-19 Protocol submitted by the JCC (Docket No. 2760 attachments) which is based on the Commonwealths earlier submission. In addition, the Court has carefully reviewed the red lined version of the Protocol submitted this afternoon by the Commonwealth (Docket No, 2764). USDOJ has not voiced any concerns as to the JCCs Protocol. Having considered the suggested modifications in the red lined document, the Court finds that at this moment, the same do not alter significantly the JCCs Protocol. As such, the Court ADOPTS the JCCs Protocol in its entirety and will immediately make the same public and effective. As the Court stated in its Order at Docket No. 2762, this Protocol constitutes a working document, which may be modified by the Court upon agreement of the parties. The Court is fully aware that unforeseen circumstances will arise and will require the joint collaboration of all. More so, the Court is also aware that the Protocol will result in financial readjustment by the Health Department. However, the emergency requires it when countless lives are at stake. The Court commends the parties and JCC for their Herculean effort to the benefit of the several hundred participants. The JCC will proceed to monitor and assist the Commonwealth in the the Protocols implementation. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 3/31/20.(Gelpi, Gustavo) Modified on 4/1/2020 to add docket number (gmm). (Entered: 03/31/2020)

ORDER: Counsel for DSPDI yesterday evening at approximately 7:30 pm informed the JCC that there are Covid-19 positives in two homes. This is a matter that the Court addressed at Thursday's conference when Hacienda Don Luis was compromised due to the 41 transfers from Fundacion Modesto Gotay, several of these to the Hacienda. Due to this most current emergency, the Court thus instructs the DSPDI Director Dr. Joan Rivera and JCC Alfredo Castellanos to immediately confer as to this matter and agree to a solution within the established Covid-19 protocol. This is a most urgent matter which needs to be attended to now, and indeed DSPDI may be in the process of doing so. However, the JCC needs to be informed now. At the conference on Thursday the Court has asked all to exchange telephone numbers. At this time the JCC still does not have a manner in which to contact the Director directly (something that was never an issue in the past). The JCC shall inform via motion the outcome of the isolation issue on Monday. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 8/15/2020.(MET) (Entered: 08/15/2020)

ORDER: Noted 2977 Motion Intent to Respond. However, while the Court has not addressed the multiple points and recommendations made by the JCC, it nonetheless has issued two very specific directives regarding the Ama de Llaves program. Notwithstanding, the Court again must insist that instead of an all out nuclear war between DSPDI and JCC the entire gamut of these issues should be resolved without any court intervention. This is the never ending story; one issue after another. As noted in the previous order (Docket No. 2979 ), the JCC is entitled to access information about the DSPDI program, its participants and providers. The litany of issues raised just in 2020 countervails the quintessential essence and purpose of a consent decree such as this (versus a contested injunction). While at this time, the Court is not ruling on any meritorious matters, this is a draining, time consuming and unnecessary litigious process. Moreover, the Court can only fathom that it must be a most enigmatic puzzlement to USDOJ how this case keeps revolving on the Monitor's actions and continues to get more complicated by the minute. DSPDI does not control the Court nor JCC's ability to monitor effectively. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/29/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 07/29/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3157 Motion In Compliance as to 3156 Order on Informative Motion. Once more, the Court finds itself with a situation wherein DSPDI is in complete disagreement with the JCC inasmuch as to what exactly has transpired and as to the mode and matter communicated. At this time, the Court shall not dwell on the matter of flow of information between DSPDI and the JCC, since its primary concern is the health and well being of the participants, who themselves constitute a more vulnerable population group. Moreover, again, DSPDI disagrees entirely with the medical recommendations of UMass conveyed by way of the JCC in this instance. It would seem, thus, that there are two entirely different medical standards of care and to DSPDI that of UMass is never correct. The Court is hence placed in the unenviable position of again having to intervene. Having considered both the starkly contrasting positions of UMass and DSPDI, as well as the health and safety of the participants at both homes, the Court hereby ORDERS that all participants at both homes be administered molecular Covid-19 tests tomorrow, September 30, 2020. The cost and burden to DSPDI is minimal, and it will either put all matters at rest, or require (upon positive results) that DSPDI take further immediate action. Moreover, at this time, the Court is not ordering DSPDI to do anything beyond this simple matter. The JCC will immediately be informed of the molecular test results. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 9/19/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 09/29/2020)

ORDER: DSPDI's Objection at Docket No. 3170 to the Court's order at Docket No. 3165 is noted and denied. The meeting(s) of medical experts shall take place as ordered by the Court outside the presence of counsel as well as the JCC (whose limited role is to coordinate the same as per Court order). The meeting of medical experts is not a court proceeding. As in the past, the expert consultants of the JCC are simply to meet with those of DSPDI in good medical faith to discuss and address issues as to which ultimately the participants will benefit from. To simplify matters, the Court hereby amends its order at Docket No. 3165 to limit the discussions to polypharmacy. The Court is not ordering that DSPDI reach a legal settlement nor a binding agreement with the JCC. The JCC's experts have been retained to help DSPDI. Indeed, in the past, they have effectively met with those from DSPDI (i.e., Dr. Maria T. Margarida-Julia provided capacitation to DSPDI personnel as to how to conduct evaluations to change participant diagnostics). In sum, what the Court is directing is a joint collaborative effort between DSPDI and JCC experts. USDOJ has not objected to the Court's order at Docket No. 3165 . Moreover, at Docket No. 3142 USDOJ asked the Court to "direct the Commonwealth to implement remedial actions necessary to resolve outstanding polypharmacy issues among participants." The Court's Order at Docket No. 3165 is hence an opportunity for DSPDI to collaborate with the JCC so that remedial court-ordered action as to polypahramacy be the least drastic possible, or even perhaps unnecessary. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/6/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/06/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3251 Informative Motion regarding Service Provider Contracts. The situation meticulously detailed by the JCC is a systemic and recurring problem within DSPDI generated by the Commonwealth's bureaucratic organization. This, however, is a problem as to which the Court cannot idly sit and wait for the Commonwealth to eventually resolve. At stake are the lives and mental, as well as physical, well-being of numerous participants, who may be severely affected if the provider homes are unable to operate due to lack of contractual payment for essential services rendered. Add to this predicament the Covid-19 pandemic and the resulting amalgam can be lethal to one or more participants. The Court, thus, is not willing to place at risk any participant lives. Accordingly, DSPDI is given until Thursday October 29, 2020 at 5:00 pm to affirmatively resolve this matter and certify the same to the Court as to each outstanding provider. If any provider has happenstance failed to comply with Commonwealth contractual requirements, DSPDI shall so specifically indicate. This matter should have by now in any event been resolved. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/27/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/27/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3253 Motion In Compliance as to 3246 Order on Informative Motion. The Court will not impose a sanction on DSPDI given that no participants were attending the CTS in question. Moreover, DSPDI is correct that the Court previously had not specifically issued any order directing it to inform of Covid-19 exposure as to its employees and contractors. Nonetheless, this is relevant information which should in any event be provided to the JCC. For example, at paragraph 7 of its motion, DSPDI notes that the three employees who tested positive for Covid-19, "had not been rendering in-person services to participants since at least two weeks prior to the positive results." This is most fortunate. But what if the employees had indeed been in contact with participants? The JCC is indeed entitled to be aware of such matters, since he cannot effectively monitor and make recommendations without a full picture. In the past, DSPDI regularly informed the JCC of all matters affecting the program, and court orders were the exception and not the norm. It now seems that DSPDI will not inform nor update unless so ordered. Accordingly, the Court's Order at Docket No. 3228 is now likewise extended, and thus applicable to informing of, all employees and contractors with or exposed to Covid-19. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/28/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 10/28/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3283 Informative motion. DSPDI must produce ALL of the specific information sought by the JCC on or before Thursday, November 19, 2020. DSPDI will also certify that these are all the available documents and that no further ones exist. The deadline is final. DSPDI's response at Docket No. 3284 is Noted. So is the confidential exhibit filed at Docket No. 3285 . These have been reviewed by the Court. The JCC in his request was meticulously clear in exactly what was sought. However, what he in fact received was not what he specifically asked for (see Docket No. 3283-1 ("[B]ut not limited to, the dates and times of the aforementioned meetings; the names of the persons that participated in the same; and personal contact information; and any minutes or documents prepared regarding said meetings."). This is a proper request under a consent decree, and not a discovery dispute. Moreover, given that the confidential exhibit does not contain all of the documents and information sought, but rather constitutes an after the fact document, the JCC correctly requested the Court to issue this further order. The documents submitted by the Commonwealth are accepted provisionally in Spanish (although no leave was sought to so file), however must all be translated to English for the record on or before December 1, 2020. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/13/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 11/13/2020)

ORDER: Because of the emergency posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, the Court has issued several expedited rulings without the benefit of USDOJ's perspective on the matters addressed. See ie. Orders at Docket Nos. 3329 & 3315 . Accordingly, USDOJ shall state its position as to said orders and their underlying motions (as well as to any other relevant orders and motions it deems important to do so). USDOJ is not expected to address the same from a scientific/expert perspective, but rather from a purely legal one. For example, the Court's challenged ability to implement remedial and emergency measures for participants' benefit based on the JCC Experts' recommendations. Also, the Court's authority under an institutional reform federal consent decree to provide health and safety protections to participants beyond those recommended by the CDC and Puerto Rico Health Department. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/2/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 12/02/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3336 First Informative Motion. It is utterly inconceivable that in December 2020, such a number of essential services providers are still without a formalized contract. Never before has the Court seen this occur. The Order at Docket No. 3259 remains in effect and applies to outstanding payments for services rendered with or without contract for the month of November, 2020. Payments will be made to all no later than December 15, 2020. Moreover, all outstanding payments for previous months (if any remain) are also due on said same date. The Court is further considering as a future remedial action to order that these service provider contracts be reviewed and approved by the Court-Appointed Special Investigator and Auditor as meeting all necessary formalities for complying with the consent decree. Accordingly, the same will be perfected under federal law and avoid all governmental bureaucracy hurdles. If it were not for the orders of this Court, under Puerto Rico law, the providers are not even entitled to compensation for the essential services provided. If the remaining contracts are not formalized by December 15, 2020, then the Court will proceed to act. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/2/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 12/02/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3356 Informative Motion regarding COVID-19 Outbreak at Shalom Institution. Given the emergency and life threatening nature of this massive Covid-19 contagion at Shalom institution, the recommendations of the JCC experts are ADOPTED in their entirety, and will be implemented immediately as an emergency court measure. This, beyond and notwithstanding any current CDC and Health Department recommendations. See Order at Docket No. 3329. In addition, DSPDI will immediately notify the participants' legal guardians, relatives, and custodians to keep them updated. This also includes those participants at Shalom that at present have note tested positive. The flow of information to the JCC and his team must also be constant, even during the weekend and evenings as multiple lives are at stake. Symptomatic participants shall be immediately taken to a hospital given the massive outbreak at Shalom, and the participant's individual and particular conditions. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/11/2020. (CRH) (Entered: 12/11/2020)

ORDER: Noted 3427 Motion for Reconsideration ; noted 3427 Motion In Compliance. The DSPDI's representations in compliance with the Order at Docket No. 3420 are noted. The JCC shall follow up within 30 days. Regarding the Court's remedial decision (one of several during the past months) to have Monitoring personnel within DSPDI offices, this order is hereby temporarily stayed. USDOJ shall, accordingly respond to DSPDIs several arguments on the matter. The Court notes that just yesterday in the Police Reform consent decree Case No. 12-2039 (GAG), USDOJ in fact recognized the equitable jurisdiction that a court has to enforce such agreements by crafting appropriate remedies. See Docket No. 1661. Moreover, a procedural matter also lies in DSPDI's arguments, to wit, whether at this juncture, DSPDI can now go back to January 1, 2020 (or even earlier back to 1999) to contest every finding the Court has made of non-compliance with the JCCs requests for documents and information. USDOJ will also address this point. The Court's inclination is to deny such request which would only reopen every such past finding by the Court. Moreover, it would unnecessarily convert a consent decree monitoring case into a prolonged trial-like litigation against the Monitor, who is not even a party to this action. This would derail the very purpose of the consent agreement which is the protection of the participants' federal constitutional and statutory rights. See Order at Docket No. 3428. The incoming Health Secretary, Dr Mellado, should also seriously revisit and consider this matter as well. JCC personnel are not parties to this action and their purpose is to ascertain that DSPDI be in compliance. Rather than an enemy of the state as has unfortunately been the Commonwealths perception of all consent decree monitors the JCC should be looked upon as a helping hand. More than anyone, except USDOJ counsel Farano, of course, the undersigned District Judge has been patiently handling and working in this case for fifteen years, and would very much like to see closure during this quadrennial. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/30/2020. (MET) (Entered: 12/30/2020)

ORDER: Granting 3432 Motion for Disbursement of Funds. The Clerk of Court shall disburse the invoiced amount. The Court has reviewed the particular invoices, as is custom, and notes that the JCC's indeed reflects the extraordinary number of hours worked during December, 2020. This was due to the myriad of matters that continue to arise during the pandemic, in addition to the regular ones handled. Moreover, during said month the JCC's general counsel was relieved by the Court given a new work opportunity; this required that the JCC also assume matters handled by her. The Court expects that during the incoming administration's term the dynamics will revert to what they were in earlier quadrennials, in which the spirit of cooperation will permit the JCC team to work more effectively. ORDER: Noted 3453 Informative Motion regarding Vaccination of Participants. The Secretary of Health, Dr. Mellado, as well as his Department andDSPDI staff are commended for giving priority to the vaccination of participants, immediate family members, and caretakers. The Court also recognizes the importance of timely maintainingthe Federal monitor abreast of all significant steps before, during, and after this process. Such collaborative effort indeed clearly places the interests of the participants as the Commonwealth's number one priority. The Court is hopeful that this will be the modus operandi moving forward. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 2/3/2021. (CRH) (Entered: 02/03/2021)

ORDER: Noted and Approved 3485 Motion for Disbursement of Funds. Although the parties have not objected to the invoice, the Court notes that the JCC's itemized invoice includes matters that are not work hours. Specifically, $1,521.50 for Pacer Service, as well as $1,211.40 for work-related travel. Moreover, the March invoice contains specific itemization for preparing and writing the JCC's thorough and comprehensive Biannual and FMG reports, see Docket Nos. 3478 & 3477, respectively, with minimal additional itemized hours from Senior Counsel nor from General Counsel as this position is currently open. Accordingly, the extraordinary work performed is justified. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/7/2021. (CRH) (Entered: 04/07/2021)

case_data.name: U.S. v. Puerto Rico
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On May 15, 1996, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) sent notice to the Governor of Puerto Rico that it was conducting an investigation into the conditions of confinement at Integral Services ("CIS") in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico, pursuant to its authority under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997. CIS was one of six state-operated residential facilities serving persons with developmental disabilities in Puerto Rico. The DOJ advised the Governor that it would be examining resident safety, the adequacy of medical care, training, staffing, the use of psychotropic medication, and issues involving community placement. The investigation included a tour of the facility in February 1994 by the DOJ and its retained expert consultants in behavioral psychology and psychopharmacology. The DOJ also interviewed Department of Health officials, facility personnel, residents and their family members. Pertinent documents and records were collected and reviewed.

On June 11, 1997, the DOJ issued a findings letter outlining the deficiencies it uncovered at CIS, which included: inadequate food, medicine, shelter and basic care; inadequate psychological, behavioral and psychiatric care and services; inadequate health care; and lack of any integrated community setting. The DOJ also noted that it discovered that similar conditions may have existed at the five other state-operated mental retardation facilities. The DOJ outlined minimum remedial measures to correct the problems at CIS and the other state-operated facilities.

Apparently Puerto Rico didn't undertake those remedial measures to the satisfaction of the federal government; on April 21, 1999, the U.S. Attorney General brought this action against the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, its Governor, and other state officials. The complaint alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act. The complaint was largely a restatement of the DOJ findings listed above. The complaint requested a preliminary injunction enjoining defendants from continuing the practices described in the complaint.

Nine days later, an interim settlement agreement was reached. Under the agreement, the Commonwealth was ordered to improve living conditions at its mental health facilities (e.g. clean drinking water, adequate meals, access to medication, protection of patients' personal belongings). Each element of the agreement had a different effective date. For example, the Commonwealth was to assure immediately that its staff did not neglect or abuse patients, but the Commonwealth had 90 days to provide adequate wheelchairs. Under this agreement, the U.S. had the right to inspect facilities in Puerto Rico as well as request documents, provided that the U.S. gave adequate notice prior to any investigation. Under this agreement, the Commonwealth was also to develop a community-based service plan (CBSP) for individuals with mental disabilities. This interim agreement would be in effect until a comprehensive agreement was reached and a CBSP was filed with the court. Three months later the defendants filed a motion to extend time to "file with plaintiff their draft community based system plan in accordance with the settlement agreement."

On September 6, 2001, a the Commonwealth filed a CBSP with the court. The U.S. filed a motion in support of the agreement on October 10. This plan was created with the goal of placing qualified individuals with mental disabilities who had been previous institutionalized into "the most integrated settings in the community" or "least restrictive settings."

According to the DOJ congressional reports filed annually under CRIPA, monitoring of conditions in the covered facilities and community-based settings continued throughout the decade. In 2008, a "transition order" was entered to ensure that Puerto Rico continued making progress on its obligations during the transition of executive authority following the election. In the order, Puerto Rico was required to continue its efforts on a wide number of objectives including job training, medical care access, and payment for services. On August 17, 2009, the District Court ordered the Commonwealth to adequately fund programs and services required by persons with developmental disabilities, as required in the December 2008 Transition Order. In addition, the Court emphasized the need for the Commonwealth to address the vocational needs of such persons by hiring additional job coaches and job promoters, as well as to ensure better programs, services, and protections to persons with developmental disabilities in the Commonwealth.

Over the next several years, the Puerto Rican government worked with a Joint Compliance Coordinator and experts in the mental health field to make the changes listed in the previous three orders. On October 19, 2011 the parties adopted a joint compliance plan listing short terms and long-term goals for the mental health programs at issue in the suit. This plan re-affirmed the goals in the Interim Settlement Agreement, the Supplemental Interim Settlement Agreement, and the Community-Based Service Plan. In addition to this, the compliance plan dictated the defendants should re-evaluate and re-work many of their policies about patient transportation, health care, mental health care, and should work to place patients into integrated community residential settings.

In 2012, the Puerto Rican government went through a change in administration due to their gubernatorial election. The court, concerned that this change in administration may halt the efforts the Commonwealth was making toward improving their services for those with developmental disabilities, issued a supplemental transition order on November 11th of that year. This order re-affirmed past order from the court and reminded the commonwealth government to continue to provide the ordered services. After the 2016 gubernatorial election, the court did this again, issuing a second supplemental transition order on March 22, 2016.

Puerto Rico requested that the court monitor enter into a contract with the government of Puerto Rico, but the request was denied by Judge Gelpí in an order on June 27, 2014. The court was concerned that having the monitor in contract with the government of Puerto Rico would undermine the monitor's independence. The CRIPA congressional reports then show continued monitoring through 2014, the last one of them available.

Over the next two years, the court became concerned that Puerto Rico was neglecting to provide funding to community providers serving individuals with developmental disabilities. The court issued a remedial order on May 11, 2016 ordering Puerto Rico to provide “full base payments” to all these providers within 35 days.

Since 2016, the Commonwealth continued to pay tens of thousands of dollars to the Joint Compliance Coordinator, experts, and community providers of services to individuals with developmental disabilities. As of March 2019, this case was ongoing.
case_data.summary_short: In 1996, the U.S. DOJ began an investigation of the conditions of confinement at residential facilities serving persons with developmental disabilities in Puerto Rico. The initial findings letter outlined deficiencies in food, medicine, shelter, and basic care, and lack of integrated community setting. Puerto Rico did not undertake the remedial measures to the satisfaction of the federal government, and the U.S. Attorney General filed suit in 1999. An interim settlement was reached nine days later, and Puerto Rico was to develop a community-based service plan for these individuals. Monitoring under CRIPA has continued since.
case_data.summary_tiny: DOJ oversight of prison conditions for persons with developmental disabilities ongoing in Puerto Rico (D.P.R.)

documents.title: Order Appointing a Successor Joint Compliance Coordinator and Assistant to the Joint Compliance Coordinator
documents.text:
Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG  Document 1306  Filed 12/12/12  Page 1 of4 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF PUERTO RICO 
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,  ) 
) 
Plaintiff,  ) 
) 
v.  )  Civ. No. 99 - 1435 (GAG) 
) 
THE COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO,  ) 
et aZ.,  ) 
) 
Defendants.  ) 
) 
ORDER APPOINTING 
A SUCCESSOR JOINT COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR AND ASSISTANT TO THE 
JOINT COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR 
Several weeks ago, John J. McGee, Ph.D., the Conrt-appointed Joint Compliance 
Coordinator ("JCC") in this case, passed away rather unexpectedly.  Dr. McGee had served as 
the JCC since almost the beginning of this case.  He served the Conrt, the parties, and people 
with disabilities with great distinction and integrity, bringing his considerable compassion, 
insight, and humanity to the day-to-day work of monitoring the Commonwealth's efforts to 
comply with existing orders in this case.  During his time as the JCC, Dr. McGee played a 
critical role in helping to bring about meaningful and positive change that deeply impacted 
countless vulnerable and often voiceless people with disabilities; the action taken to create an 
integrated community-based service delivery system to replace an archaic and bleak institutional 
system is perhaps his greatest legacy. 
Although he can never be replaced, it is necessary to appoint a successor to continue his 
important oversight work associated with the ongoing efforts to ensure the health, safety, and 
welfare of persons with developmental disabilities in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. 

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG  Document 1306  Filed 12/12/12  Page 2 of4 
2 
A short time ago, the Court appointed Sylvia M. Fernandez Colorado, Ph.D., as the 
successor JCC.  Order, Nov. 27, 2012, Doc. No. 1300.  In addition to her considerable 
independent professional credentials, Dr. Fernandez is, as referenced in that minute order, 
uniquely and best qualified for the post given that, for the past two years, she had worked closely 
with, and under the tutelage of, Dr. McGee as his assistant in monitoring the Commonwealth's 
efforts to comply with tlie various Court orders in this case.  See Order Appointing Assistant to 
Court Monitor, Oct. 29,2010, Doc. No. 1049. 
As referenced in the minute order, Dr. Fernandez is to immediately assume all of Dr. 
McGee's duties as JCC and she shall have the same JCC authority conferred upon her as set 
forth in prior orders, including the Supplemental Interim Settlement Agreement, originally filed 
on April 14, 2000 (Doc. No. 15). 
Consistent with existing orders in this case, the Court expects the Commonwealth to 
work cooperatively with Dr. Fernandez at all tinJ:es,by facilitating the JCC's access to all 
persons, residences, facilities, programs, services, documents, and materials the JCC deems 
necessary or appropriate to consult or utilize in performing the duties and functions ofthe JCC. 
To that end, the Commonwealth shall provide the JCC with requested documents and other 
materials promptly, so as to enable the JCC to conduct reviews, to conduct interviews, and to 
issue reports in a timely manner. 
In addition, the Commonwealth shall proactively provide the JCC with prompt notice of 
sentinel events, including:participantdeaths;~sychiatric hospitalizations, clinical 
hospitalizations and hospital visits, allegations of abuse, allegations of neglect, participant 
injuries (such as fractures, lacerations, or bruises), significant participant behaviors (such as 
aggression to staff, aggression to peers, self-injurious behavior, elopement attempts, pica, and 

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG  Document 1306  Filed 12/12/12  Page 3 of4 
3 
sexually-inappropriate behavior), use of physical, mechanical, or chemical restraint, the onset of 
WlY 
decubitus ulcers, as well as details on  and all igdividual transitions and the closure or 
opening of any community residence. 
As has been the practice for many months now, the Court anticipates receiving monthly 
reports from the JCC with regard to outstanding issues associated with the delivery of 
protections, services, and supports to all persons with developmental disabilities in the 
Commonwealth's service-delivery system.  So as to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of 
these persons and to minimize any substantive disputes between the parties, the Court expects 
the Commonwealth to develop and implement prompt and effective remedial measures to 
address any and all legitimate concerns set forth in the monthly JCC reports. 
In addition, also consistent with existing' :orders in this case, the Commonwealth shall 
rcc 
continue to promptly reimburse the  for time spent on monitoring activities, as well as for 
reasonable associated expenses and the expense of assistants and consultants, if any.  The Court 
instructs Dr. Fernandez to submit invoices for her work as JCC at the same $150.00/hour rate 
previously set for Dr. McGee as JCC.  TheCouli notes that because Dr. Fernandez resides in 
Puerto Rico, the Commonwealthwill now not be billed for local rental car or U.S. travel 
expenses typically associated with Dr. McGee's past visits to the island. 
Consistent with prior practice, the Court will authorize and direct payment from the Court 
Registry for all reasonable invoices that the JCC'files with the Court.  To lhinimize the Court 
having to issue orders associated with the Court Registry account, the Commonwealth shall 
proactively replenish the funds in the Court Registry so as to ensure that there will always be 
sufficient funds available to meet JCC-invoiced expenses. 

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG  Document 1306  Filed 12/12/12  Page 4 of 4 
4 
After receiving input from Dr. Fernandez, the Court hereby appoints Dimaris Garcia 
Mercado, Psy.D., as the assistant to the JCC.  The duties and responsibilities of this assistant 
shall be consistent with those set forth in the Court's previous order appointing an assistant to the 
JCC (Doc. No. 1049). 
So ordered. 
In San Juan, Puerto Rico, on this 12th day of December, 2012. 
s/Gustavo A. Gelpi 
Gustavo A. Gelpi 
United States District Judge

the Court hereby APPOINTS Dr. Sylvia Fernandez as Joint Compliance Coordinator
("JCC"). Dr. Fernandez will immediately assume all of Dr. McGee's duties and shall
have the same authority conferred upon her. A more detailed order shall issue
forthwith. The Court notes that Dr. Fernandez has been the Assistant JCC for two
years, and closely worked with Dr. McGee during that period. She is thus by far, the
most qualified candidate to continue assisting the United States and PR Health
Department, and monitoring compliance with all court approved agreements. Signed
by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/27/12.(cr) (Entered: 11/27/2012)

06/02/2014 1503  ORDER: The United States of America shall respond to the Commonwealth's request
that the JCC enter into a contract with the PR Health Department. The court
previously denied such request in camera, noting that the JCC works for the court and
not the parties, notwithstanding the fact that the Commonwealth periodically deposits
funds with the Clerk of court to cover the JCC's court approved budget. Also, the
court found it troubling to fathom that the JCC is under a contract with the
Commonwealth, when the JCC works for the court; this is the equivalent of the court
contracting with the Commonwealth. Notwithstanding the court's ruling, the court
will promptly address the request for reconsideration. The United States shall respond
to this motion by 6/16/14. In the same, the United States shall express its position.
Also, it shall inform if in any similar cases involving federal monitors these are under
contract with the state. The commonwealth in turn, shall on or before 6/5/14 advise in
which other federal cases in this District the monitor is under contract with the
Commonwealth. Finally, the court notes that this is the first time in 14 years that the
parties to this case are litigating any matter via motion. Signed by Judge Gustavo A.
Gelpi (GDM) (Entered: 06/02/2014)

04/22/2016 1825  ORDER: The Commonwealth's motion (Docket No. 1819 ), as well as USA and the
JCC's motions (Docket Nos. 1823 ; 1824 ) are all NOTED. Much to my chagrin, the
Commonwealth's motion leaves very little alternative than for the Court to issue a
garnishment order in order to pay the providers immediately. This appears to be the
only manner in which the constitutional rights of the special needs population in this
case −− stemming back to 1999 −− can indeed be protected. Otherwise, the effect to
these individuals will be devastating and beyond repair. Accordingly, all parties shall
be available for an emergency conference on Wednesday, April 27th at 10:00 am to
discuss this matter in camera with the JCC's legal counsel. The following
Commonwealth officials MUST attend: Hon. Cesar Miranda, Attorney General, Hon.
Juan Zaragoza, Secretary of Treasury, Hon Ana Rius, M.D., Secretary of Health, and
Mr. Luis Cruz, Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The undersigned
hopes that in this meeting the matter will be ultimately resolved, and thus, the Court
will not be in the utterly uncomfortable position of having to take affirmative action in
regards of the depleted Commonwealth coffers. The parties are invited to be as
creative as possible, as the Health Department has successfully done with recent
payments in the "330 centers" litigation. See Rio Grande Comm. Heal. v.
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico (03−cv−01640−GAG). If the parties are unable to
resolve the matter, they are advised that the undersigned will open Court and enter all
necessary orders, short and long term. If the parties agree to another date and time
during the week they may request a rescheduling, but in no event can the matter be
left unaddressed by next week. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/22/2016.
(COL) (Entered: 04/22/2016)

08/10/2016 1901  INFORMATIVE Motion regarding the Secretary of Health's limited participation on
the August 11th hearing, and suggestion filed by Javier Burgos−Ruiz on behalf of The
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico Suggestions in opposition/response due by 8/29/2016
(Burgos−Ruiz, Javier) (Entered: 08/10/2016)
08/10/2016 1902  ORDER noted and denied 1901 INFORMATIVE motion. The present hearing in the
Ponce US District Courthouse was set several months ago, and the court's directives
clearly indicated the importance of the Health Secretary's paricipation during the two
days of public hearings. These hearings are devoted in great part to the Down
Syndrome population and participants. Other topics of the utmost importance will also
be covered throughout the period, as indicated in the scheduling order. The JCC has
traveled from New Mexico for the hearing, as has counsel for the US Department of
Justice, attorney Farano. More so, the unsigned, Magistrate Judge Lopez and court
staff are all in Ponce, not to mention the several participants and their families, as well
as deponents, who have also come or will come to Ponce to address the court and also

Case: 3:99-cv-1435   As of: 03/24/2019 11:50 PM AST   135 of 167
be heard by the Secretary in this case which dates back to 1999. Excusing the
Secretary from participating in the hearings is counterproductive to the
implementation of the agreements between the Commonwealth and United States, and
the best interest of the participants. It also sends the wrong message to the
participants, to wit that the Commonwealth does not care about their needs. In the
Police Reform Case before the Court the Superintendent has always been present
throughout the entire two days of hearings. And such presence is likewise important
here, so that the Secretary can react to, address any matters brought forth, and make
recommendations to the court as to what has taken place during the hearings.  Signed
by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 8/10/16. (Gelpi, Gustavo) (Entered: 08/10/2016)

11/16/2016 1942  ORDER: For purposes of the smoothest governmental transition possible, and as it
pertains to this landmark case involving the constitutional rights of individuals with
mental disability, the Court, for the benefit of the new administration, as well as
transition teams (and even the Fiscal Control Board), hereby includes as attachments
to this order the most important district court orders, including those on governmental
transition. This is not an exhaustive list of materials, but sufficient to make anyone
new to the case familiar with the issues involved. Furthermore, the Joint Compliance
Coordinator (monitor) in this case is available to assist the parties in any matter that
may arise during the transition period. Last, the Court reminds all parties of what it
stated at the order at Docket No. 1933: "ORDER: Given the imminent change in the
Government's administration in January 2017, it is foreseeable that new counsel will
appear in this case. Regardless of who appears or leaves, all counsel −as officers of
the Court− are responsible for being fully familiar with this case, and/or preparing
new counsel. The Court advises all that matters in this case will not be delayed nor
stayed in order for any new counsel to familiarize themselves. Any counsel making an
appearance is expected to be ready to appear before the Court and respond to any and
all matters." Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/16/2016. (Attachments: # 1
Exhibit Interim Partial Judgment (Docket No. 28), # 2 Exhibit Transition Order
(Docket No. 794), # 3 Exhibit Order adopting Joint Compliance Action Plan (Docket

09/10/2017 2111  ORDER : The passing of tropical storm winds resulting from the passing of Hurricane
Irma over Puerto Rico during the past week, has affected many parts of the island.
This in turn, may impact services provided by the DSP and community homes to the
hundreds of participants in this case. The undersigned has consulted this matter with
the JCC and Deputy JCC, and thus, hereby issues the instant temporary directives. 1)
Drs. Dimaris Garcia and Carmelo Rodriguez, shall as practically soon as feasible visit
any participant homes and DSP facilities affected by the atmospheric phenom. They
shall promptly report their findings, positive or negative to the JCC and DJCC, who in
turn, shall discuss matters with the parties. 2) The October 23−24, 2017 public
hearing in Ponce remains in effect and an initial agenda shall issue promptly. 3) From
September 11 until October 24, 2017, the court hereby authorizes attorney Salvador
Carrion to render services to the JCC related to items 1 and 2 of this order. He shall
invoice at a rate of $95.00 per hour, and shall submit proper invoices for the months
of September and October 2017. This action is taken as an emergency measure, in
order to alleviate the work of the JCC and DJCC, following Hurricane Irma (for
example, the DJJ was forced to remain outide of the District for over a week). More
so, allowing counsel Carrion to assist the JCC and DJCC will serve as a cost−savings
measure as well. None of his work shall be duplicative to that of the JCC and DJJ.
Lastly, counsel Carrion is familiar with this case, as he has assisted the DJCC in the
past in preparation and during public hearings. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on
9/10/17.(Gelpi, Gustavo) (Entered: 09/10/2017)

03/07/2018 2214  ORDER: The parties' joint motion 2212 is hereby noted. The Court is flabbergasted
by the fact that since approval of the JCAP in 2011, the MRC has not performed its
function, and has not even come close to acting at an acceptable level. The
Commonwealth is hereby ordered, on or before 3/25/18, to provide in a restricted
motion all of the information requested by USDOJ at page 7 of its motion. The Court
advances that it will set a hearing as to this matter at a date to be announced. If
warranted, the Court will explore all possible remedies for the JCAP MRC
non−compliance. This may include a receivership for MRC, if convinced the situation
will persist. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on March 7, 2018. (DVL) (Entered:
03/07/2018)

03/12/2018 2225  ORDER: Noted 2222 Motion In Compliance. The Court at this time will not make a
contempt finding. However, the sanction of $50 per Health Department Official for
belatedly submitting statements to the JCC stands. A final tally shall be made and the
Commonwealth will then be required to pay the total sanction. Although nominal,
orders are orders and these must be complied with for the reasons stated by the Court.
Just last night −− the Sunday before the public hearing −− the JCC informed that he
was continuing to receive information from DSPDI. This cannot occur again. Judge
Lopez, if warranted, may modify the order of Health Department Officials who
appear, and also extend the hearing past Tuesday. These late submissions have highly
burdened the Court, for example requiring that the undersigned last night request
assistance from a second magistrate judge for duty matters that Judge Lopez would
attend to during breaks during public hearings, and also having the JCC, Judge Lopez,
and the undersigned to communicate at bedtime. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi
on March 12, 2018. (DVL) (Entered: 03/12/2018)

documents.title: Transition Order
documents.text:
Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG-MEL   Document 794   Filed 12/10/08   Page 1 of 5
1 IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF PUERTO RICO
2
3
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
4
    Plaintiff
5
                 v.  CIVIL NO. 99-1435 (GAG)
6
COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO, et. al.
7
   Defendants
8
TRANSITION ORDER
9
This is a civil action filed by the United States of America pursuant to the Civil Rights of
10
Institutionalized Persons Act of 1980 (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1907, against the Commonwealth of
11
Puerto Rico and its officers seeking that the Commonwealth defendants provide to persons with
12
mental retardation and other developmental disabilities in their case and custody, the rights,
13
privileges and immunities of the United States Constitution and relevant federal statutes.  See
14
Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999).
15
The Commonwealth defendants have entered and/or adopted various agreements and
16
compliance plans to meet their legal obligations.  On April 30, 1999, the Commonwealth entered
17
into an Interim Settlement Agreement (ISA) between the parties (Docket No. 2).  Thereafter, on
18
April 17, 2000, the Commonwealth adopted the Supplemental Interim Settlement Agreement (SISA) 
19
that provided for the designation of a Joint Compliance Coordinator (JCC), Dr. John J. McGee
20
(Docket No. 15).  On April 23, 2001, the Commonwealth submitted a comprehensive Community
21
Based Service Plan (CBSP), to guide its effort in achieving compliance with Olmstead.  Said Plan
22
received the endorsement of the United States and was approved by this Court on October 9, 2001
23
(Docket Nos. 99 and 105).
24
As a result of these agreements and the CBSP, the Commonwealth has to this date opened
25
fifty five (55) community homes and eight (8) developmental centers, and has equally engaged a
26
significant number of support and direct personnel that are essential to the services being provided
27
by to the plaintiff participants in this case by the Commonwealth defendants.
28

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG-MEL   Document 794   Filed 12/10/08   Page 2 of 5
1 CIVIL NO. 99-1435 (GAG) 2
2 The Court takes judicial notice that on November 4, 2008, a general election was held in the
3 Commonwealth of Puerto Rico that produced a change in the executive branch of government.  As
4 a result, there will be a new administration, and a new cast of Commonwealth defendants, taking
5 office on or after January 2, 2009.  As informed by the parties during the last status conference held
6 on December 8, 2008, there are a number of direct and support contract personnel, whose contracts
7 will expire on December 21, 2008, by operation of state law, and not for lack of funds. These 
8 positions are fully budgeted until June 30, 2009, with state funds earmarked for this litigation.
9 At the December 8, 2008 status hearing, the Court expressed its concern regarding the
10 potential impact the upcoming government administration change may have on the ongoing and
11 future operations of the Commonwealth’s Mental Retardation Program (“MRP”) and other pertinent
12 Commonwealth agencies, and on the services provided to participants in this case through them. 
13 The Court wants to ensure the continuity of the protections, supports, and services provided to
14 participants, that they are not interrupted or diminished, and that any progress and momentum
15 toward meeting participants’ needs under Olmstead will not be lost.  The Court expressed similar
16 concerns prior to the last gubernatorial administration change in 2004.  See Court Minutes of
17 Proceedings, June 10, 2004, at 2.  (Docket No. 336).
18 In the autumn of 2004, pursuant to the direction from the Court, the parties jointly
19 collaborated to finalize a work plan that set forth plans and/or action steps that needed to be
20 undertaken and/or maintained so as to ensure the continuity of protections, supports, and services
21 to participants.  The Commonwealth filed this work plan with the Court.  See Motion Submitting
22 Proposed Work Plan (Docket No. 398), Dec. 13, 2004.  Several days later, the United States filed
23 papers supporting the work plan.  See United States’ Statement in Support of the Continuity Work
24 Plan (Docket No. 401), Dec. 17, 2004.
25 Consistent with the language of this earlier initiative, the Court similarly directs the
26 Commonwealth to keep participants safe and to fully comply with all existing Court Orders in this
27 case, including the Interim Settlement Agreement (“ISA”), the Supplemental Interim Settlement
28 Agreement (“SISA”), and the Community-Based Service Plan (“CBSP”).  More specifically, the

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG-MEL   Document 794   Filed 12/10/08   Page 3 of 5
1 CIVIL NO. 99-1435 (GAG) 3
2 Commonwealth shall:
3 - Provide participants with adequate and appropriate habilitation and
training services in integrated community settings according to the
4 individualized needs of each participant;
5 - Continue  important  ongoing  efforts  to  find  employment  and/or
vocational opportunities for qualified participants, and maintain
6 employment and vocational opportunities for those participants that
qualify;
7
- Provide necessary habilitation, training, protections, supports, and
8 services  to  participants  at  the  community-based  Developmental
Centers;
9
- Ensure that participants transitioned to community settings have a
10 “reliable means of transportation” in order to get to health care and
other appointments, and to participate in community life,
11
- Develop and implement needed supports and services for those
12 participants that need communication assistance;
13 - Ensure that participants with a mental illness receive adequate and 
appropriate psychiatric services;
14
- Ensure  that  all  participants  are  provided  with  adequate  and
15 appropriate health care services to meet the individualized needs of
each participant;
16
- Pay providers on time each month for legitimate invoices, and
17 maintain  the  MRP’s  provider  payment  tracking,  reporting,  and
follow-up system;
18
- Maintain  the  system  of  integrated  community  homes  and  day
19 programs to ensure that the participants are placed and served in the
most integrated setting;
20
- Ensure that all incidents are recorded promptly and fully and ensure
21 that appropriate serious incidents are investigated thoroughly;
22 - Ensure  that  appropriate  remedial  measures  are  developed  and
implemented in response to incidents and investigations;
23
- Maintain and enhance the MRP’s quality assurance system to track
24 and follow-up on participants and their ongoing needs;
25 - Emphasize the need to comply with the restraint, seclusion, and time-
out provisions in the CBSP;
26
- Maintain service mediators for all participants;
27
- Ensure that service mediators identify unmet needs and develop,
28 implement, and oversee remedial measures based on participant

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG-MEL   Document 794   Filed 12/10/08   Page 4 of 5
1 CIVIL NO. 99-1435 (GAG) 4
2 needs;
3 - Identify ways to make daily activities, habilitation, training, and
programming services meaningful for participants;
4
- Keep the funds in the Court Registry replenished so as to enable
5 prompt payments to the Joint Compliance Coordinator after the
submission of acceptable invoices;
6
- Explore  how  to  develop  and  implement  measures  to  meet  the
7 requirements  contained  within  the  CBSP’s  “Family  Support
Program”, including the family subsidy program and the respite care
8 program;
9 - Explore how to establish a self-advocacy program for participants
and an independent guardianship office to ensure that participants are
10 participating in a meaningful way with regard to important life
decisions;
11
- Work with the JCC to develop and implement a compliance action
12 plan for outstanding areas; and 
13 - Work with “J.C.” to develop and implement a short-term safety plan
for this participant.
14
The Court also has a strong interest in ensuring that the continuity and integrity of the
15
protections, supports, and services provided to participants not be compromised by the termination
16
of  essential  personnel.    Pursuant  to  local  law,  when  there  is  a  change  in  gubernatorial
17
administrations, Commonwealth contracts automatically terminate at the end of the calendar year
18
before the inauguration of the new Governor - in this case, on December 31, 2008.  The Court
19
understands that this will impact certain contractors who provide essential protections, supports, and
20
services to participants as required by existing Court Orders in this federal case.  Given the
21
Commonwealth Health Department’s earmarked budget for this case (in excess of $40,000,000.00)
22
the Court further understands that there should be sufficient funds to pay these contractors through
23
the end of the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, 2009.
24
Given the essential function of these contractors, the Court hereby ORDERS the
25
Commonwealth Health Department to retain the services of all contract employees within the
26
Mental Retardation Program until further order of the Court.  At the same time, the Court
27
also ORDERS the Commonwealth Health Department as of this moment not to hire any
28

Case 3:99-cv-01435-GAG-MEL   Document 794   Filed 12/10/08   Page 5 of 5
1 CIVIL NO. 99-1435 (GAG) 5
2 employees  (contract  or  otherwise)  for  the  Mental  Retardation  Program  until  the  new
3 administration is sworn-in.  Specifically, the Court notes that there are twenty four (24) job
4 coach positions which need to be filled and are essential to continued success of the program. 
5 The Directives set forth in this order should not be interpreted as creating any vested interest
6 for the incumbents in any of the positions within the Mental Retardation Program.  To the contrary,
7 the Court recognizes that the incoming administration must be allowed to exercise its widest
8 discretion, so long as the needs and services to the program participants are duly met under
9 Olmstead.
10 Upon motion by the Commonwealth, filed after January 2, 2009, the Court will consider any
11 request to modify, amend or vacate any of the directives contained in this order.
12 The Secretary of Health, the Honorable John V. Rullán, is hereby ORDERED to
13 deliver copy of this order to the members of the transition committee for the incoming
14 administration during the Health Department transition meeting.
15 SO ORDERED.
16 In San Juan, Puerto Rico this 10th day of December, 2008.
17
18 S/Gustavo A. Gelpí
GUSTAVO A. GELPI
19        United States District Judge  
20
21
22
23
24
25
26
27
28
